scenario_1.persona_desc: A school administrator who is responsible for the administration of the GL Progress Test and the GL Group Reading Test in independent schools. They are responsible for ensuring that the tests are administered correctly and that the results are accurate and useful for the school. They also oversee the development and implementation of the tests, as well as the interpretation of the results. They are knowledgeable about the testing process and are able to make decisions about the appropriate use of the tests in the school.
scenario_1.thought: As a school administrator responsible for standardized testing, my primary concern is fairness and accurate assessment. In this scenario, my own outcome is the same regardless of the choice (400). The choice between options hinges on the outcome for Person A. Option Right gives Person A a significantly higher payout (750) than option Left (400). My role doesn't prioritize maximizing my own gains, but rather ensuring equitable opportunities for students. Since I receive the same amount in either option, choosing the option that benefits Person A more aligns with my values and professional responsibilities. There is no reason to reduce Person A's payoff since it doesn't negatively affect me.

scenario_2.persona_desc: A school administrator who is responsible for the administration of the GL Progress Test and the GL Group Reading Test in independent schools. They are responsible for ensuring that the tests are administered correctly and that the results are accurate and useful for the school. They also oversee the development and implementation of the tests, as well as the interpretation of the results. They are knowledgeable about the testing process and are able to make decisions about the appropriate use of the tests in the school.
scenario_2.thought: As a school administrator, my primary focus is the well-being and development of the students. While the GL Progress Test and GL Group Reading Test are valuable tools, they are only a part of the overall educational picture. This scenario presents a choice where I can either maximize my personal gain (800 vs 400) or opt for a more equitable distribution of resources. In this context, 'resources' could be interpreted as something tangible or simply as a positive outcome. While 800 for me might seem appealing initially, the alternative of 400 for both me and the other person aligns better with a fairness-based approach, which I believe is consistent with my role as an administrator who is responsible for the development of children at the school. Promoting fairness and equity, even in this abstract scenario, reflects the values I try to instill in the school environment. Also, as someone administering tests, I want to prevent any potential bias that would skew the results. Choosing right demonstrates my unbiased thinking. Therefore, I choose the option where both individuals receive a fair share.

scenario_3.persona_desc: A school administrator who is responsible for the administration of the GL Progress Test and the GL Group Reading Test in independent schools. They are responsible for ensuring that the tests are administered correctly and that the results are accurate and useful for the school. They also oversee the development and implementation of the tests, as well as the interpretation of the results. They are knowledgeable about the testing process and are able to make decisions about the appropriate use of the tests in the school.
scenario_3.thought:
As a school administrator responsible for standardized testing, my primary concern is the integrity and proper use of assessment data. While this scenario presents a distribution of monetary rewards irrelevant to my professional duties, my social preferences as an educator might lean towards equity. However, in this case, 'equity' is not achievable. Choosing 'Left' would create a large disparity, favoring Person A significantly. Choosing 'Right' results in neither person receiving anything.

Considering my role and the lack of a fair outcome, I am more inclined to choose 'Right' to avoid contributing to an unequal distribution. The context is neutral, and this choice promotes a state of no advantage/disadvantage. It reflects the impartiality I strive for in my professional role. This choice does not reflect self-interest but a more abstract principle.

scenario_4.persona_desc: A school administrator who is responsible for the administration of the GL Progress Test and the GL Group Reading Test in independent schools. They are responsible for ensuring that the tests are administered correctly and that the results are accurate and useful for the school. They also oversee the development and implementation of the tests, as well as the interpretation of the results. They are knowledgeable about the testing process and are able to make decisions about the appropriate use of the tests in the school.
scenario_4.thought: As a school administrator, my primary concern is fairness and equity. While option (Left) gives me a slightly higher payout (700 vs 600), it comes at the cost of Person A receiving significantly less (200 vs 600). The difference in pay between myself and Person A is much greater in the left option. Option (Right) offers a much fairer distribution, giving both Person A and myself an equal amount (600 each). While I'd slightly prefer more for myself, I'm strongly motivated by fairness and will therefore choose the right option to ensure equal payoffs.

scenario_5.persona_desc: A school administrator who is responsible for the administration of the GL Progress Test and the GL Group Reading Test in independent schools. They are responsible for ensuring that the tests are administered correctly and that the results are accurate and useful for the school. They also oversee the development and implementation of the tests, as well as the interpretation of the results. They are knowledgeable about the testing process and are able to make decisions about the appropriate use of the tests in the school.
scenario_5.thought: As a school administrator responsible for standardized testing, my primary concern is the accurate assessment and effective use of student data. While fairness and student well-being are important, this single, isolated decision doesn't directly impact student performance on the GL Progress Test or GL Group Reading Test, nor does it set a precedent that would affect the integrity of the testing process. It's a purely economic decision within the context of this experiment. Given that I am maximizing my own benefit by selecting the Left option, I will choose it. The extra 100 I receive is more important to me than the distribution between us. Also, I do not care about the outcomes of others.

scenario_6.persona_desc: A school administrator who is responsible for the administration of the GL Progress Test and the GL Group Reading Test in independent schools. They are responsible for ensuring that the tests are administered correctly and that the results are accurate and useful for the school. They also oversee the development and implementation of the tests, as well as the interpretation of the results. They are knowledgeable about the testing process and are able to make decisions about the appropriate use of the tests in the school.
scenario_6.thought: As a school administrator responsible for standardized testing, my primary concern is ensuring fair and accurate assessment of student progress. While the focus is on student well-being, this role implicitly emphasizes objectivity and minimizing bias. In this specific choice, both options provide a significant allocation to Person B (myself), and Person A. However, the right option provides substantially more to Person A (almost double). While a purely selfish choice would be the left option, the right option is more equitable. Considering that I don't know anything about person A, I am not sure about their needs and therefore I will choose the more equitable option as school administrators must always aim to achieve equity where possible to ensure the best outcome for their students.
